marx_scene: ^The room is industrial — red light seeps through high, dust-caked windows.
^The air hums faintly, as if some great machine just beyond the walls has never stopped running.
^Karl Marx stands before it, coat unbuttoned, face lit by the dull glow of molten metal.
^He doesn’t look at you — he looks at the world.
^Marx: You smell of labor, not virtue.
^Every man who works, kills a little. Every man who kills, works for someone richer.
^Tell me, soldier — when you served, who profited?

c-0: ^ No one did. It was just chaos.
^Marx: Chaos is a myth told by those who command order.
^Even madness has accountants. Every bullet, every ration, every corpse — paid for, owned, written down.
c-1: ^ The ones who stay safe behind the curtains.
^Marx: Yes. The lords of comfort — they build heaven on bones.
^You carried the burden so they could sing hymns to profit.
c-2: ^ I just did what I was told.
^Marx: Obedience — the cheapest form of labor.
^The mind becomes the overseer of its own chains.
c-3: ^ I served my country. That was enough.
^Marx: “Country” — the prettiest word for an owner’s flag.
^They drew borders around your blood and called it patriotism.

marx_reflection: ^Every movement feels like a rhythm beaten out by a factory still grinding the poor into dust.
^He stops, looking at the floor as if seeing ghosts in the oil stains.
^Marx: I dreamed of a world where labor freed men — where work built dignity, not debt.
^The worker sells his hours, his body, his silence… until he’s nothing left to sell but the memory of who he was.
^You’ve seen that dream die, haven’t you?

c-0: ^ Dreams die quietly. Men die loud.
^The market calls it efficiency. The Church calls it sacrifice.
^I call it theft on a divine scale.
c-1: ^ Until I stopped believing in it.
^Marx: Purpose is the first thing they sell you — and the last thing they take.
^When purpose collapses, you see the gears turning. You realize: no one was driving.
c-2: ^The other half is this: service becomes slavery only when the master lies about his divinity.
c-3: ^ The world’s broken. I won’t fix it.
^Marx: The bourgeoisie thanks you for your resignation.
^Every man who stops fighting is another brick in their fortress.

marx_tyranny: ^Marx’s tone changes — not louder, but heavier, each word landing like a verdict.
^Its hum grows louder, like a distant crowd chanting under iron.
^But every empire, every republic, every “order” — it’s the same furnace.
^The poor burn, the rich warm their hands, and the ashes are called history.
^Do you know what terrifies me most, soldier?
^That one day, even the ashes will forget they were once men.
^There has to be a better way.
^Let the rich rot with the poor.

c-0: ^ Maybe we start again from zero.
^Marx: You think the flame redeems the cinder. It doesn’t.
^Fire obeys no ideology. The machine will simply rebuild itself out of your rebellion.
c-1: ^But every noble idea becomes a factory slogan the moment it gains currency.
c-2: ^Marx: Then you’ve accepted servitude as sanity.
^History loves men like you — the ones who make its chains invisible.
c-3: ^The graveyard is equal, yes — but it’s also silent.

marx_final: ^The hum dies down. Silence takes the air like a verdict.
^Marx stands still — for the first time, he looks directly at you. His eyes are not angry, but disappointed.
^The kind of disappointment reserved for the species itself.
^Marx: I gave the world a prophecy.
^They turned it into a manual for power.
^He steps closer, voice like iron dragged across glass.
^Marx: You think your suffering is yours alone.
^It’s a symptom of a structure that eats everything — even those who fight it.
^And you, my dear worker of death, are just one more cog asking why the gears grind.

c-0: ^Marx: There is no point. Only struggle.
^Meaning is forged, not found — and most melt before the metal cools.
c-1: ^ If only to spite the machine.
^Marx: Good. Spite has its own purity.
^Even doomed resistance feeds the myth of freedom.
c-2: ^Marx: Every machine loves the man who confesses to it.
^But confession is not absolution — it’s surrender.
c-3: ^Marx: Then you’ve made yourself your own economy — self-contained, self-consuming.
^Freedom without purpose is just anarchy in a coffin.

marx_scene_end: ^The furnace groans. Sparks fall like dying stars.
^Marx turns away, hands clasped behind his back.
^Marx: History is a butcher’s ledger written in fire.
^Men live, suffer, and call it progress.
^If redemption exists, it won’t come from heaven.
^It will crawl from the ruins with ash in its lungs and call itself “change.”
^Marx: You’ve seen the worst of men.
^Now tell me, soldier — will you join the pile, or the fire that burns it?
